'Financial performance' evaluates the financials of the building ('Building performance' and 'Building value') and the tennant ('Tennant performance'). In addition, given the impact the local economy can have on tennants and value of the building, the performance of the local economy is taken into account ('Marco-economic performance').

Owners have buldings have certain repsonsibilities with respect to the health of its users ('Internal environment'). In addition, users increasingly expect and demand a certain extend of comfort ('Building comfort' and 'External environment') and features ('Health features') that enable them to work in a healthly and comfortable environment. Moreover, research has shown that this is beneficial for the overall effectiveness en efficiency of its users in terms of productivity.

'Environmental sustainability' evaluates to what extent the building impacts the environment. In determining the impact, it is important to take into account the installations that are being used and its energy performance ('Installations'), the utilties that are consumed ('Utilities'), and the extent to which features are present that further decrease the impact of the building on its external environment ('Environmental features'). Finally, it is important to take into account the overall energy performance of the building by looking at its energy index ('Energy label').

'Safety' assesses to what extent the building is safe for its users. Safety comes down to the building structure ('Building safety'), fire prevention and fire fighting ('Fire safety), crime safety ('Crime safety') and the extent to which the environment is susceptible to natural disasters ('Natural disasters').

'Usability' assesses the extent to which the building is flexible ('Building'), can be reached via various methods of transportation ('Mobility')), is located in popular areas ('Demographics'), and is located in an area with favourable market conditions ('Market')..
